title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Leaving Dunkeld by the village of Inver, we cross the Braan, and pass in succession the hamlets of Dalmarnock and Ballalachan,and a mile and a half beyond, Dalguise (Stewart, Esq.) on the left ; opposite this, on the other side of the water, is St. Colme's Farm (the Duchess of Atholl).

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Into this gulf the Braan pours itself with great fury, foaming and roaring over the massive fragments of rock which have fallen into its channel, and casting a thick cloud of spray high above the bridge.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: About a mile higher up the Braan, is the Rumbling Bridge, which is thrown across a narrow chasm, eighty feet above the waterway.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: jects, across which a path leads to Ossian's Hall, situated beside a cataract formed by a fall of the Braan.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Lodge ; Rumbling Bridge, Hermitage, Palls of the Braan, and Ossian's Cave ;

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: — The Tay with its tributaries Lochy and Dochart, Tilt, Bruar, Garry, Tummel, Lyon, Braan, Almond, Ardle, Shee, Ericht, and Isla.

title: The black watch.
author: Picken, Andrew
snippet: No untoward accident disturbing their slumbers,  the cheering light of a new day early found them again pushing on their way through the winding valley of the Braan, and striking down to the left for fear of any danger of pursuit,  passing the small lake of Loch Frenchie, and climbing hills, and winding through passes and corries, before the evening had lengthened the shadows of the hills, their sight was gladdened  with a near view of the noble Benlawers,
